A field $K$ is called algebraically closed if every nonconstant polynomial $f$ of $K[X]$ admits a zero in $K$, or in other words, if $f$ decomposes in $K[X]$ into a product of linear factors. This means that $f$ admits a product decomposition $f=c \prod_{i}\left(X-\alpha_{i}\right)$ with a constant $c \in K^{*}$ as well as zeros $\alpha_{i} \in K$.

This definition inherently involves polynomials, but it does not specifically require the concept of the degree of a polynomial to be defined or used directly. The definition focuses on the existence of roots for any nonconstant polynomial and their factorization into linear factors, which implies that these polynomials are non-zero and thus have degrees, but the specific value of the degree (the highest power with a non-zero coefficient) is not directly relevant to the definition of the field being algebraically closed.\n\nIn contrast, the degree of a polynomial is a specific measure of the highest power of the variable in the polynomial that has a non-zero coefficient. While the concept of degree is fundamental in many areas of algebra, including understanding the behavior and properties of polynomials, it is not a prerequisite for defining what it means for a field to be algebraically closed.
